passages.text: August 29, 2025 07:19 AM GMT

In July, India's oil demand returned to contraction, falling \(3\%\) YoY on weak jet fuel and naphtha demand. Refinery runs rose \(1.5\%\) MoM as TAR levels reached seasonal lows. Russian crude imports fell to a 5-month low, as EU sanctions on the Nayara refinery and narrower Urals discounts slowed imports.
In this note we summarise key data for June from the Indian Petroleum Planning and Analysis Cell (PPAC), an organisation within India's national Ministry of Petroleum.

Total oil consumption in India contracted YoY for the first time in four months in July, dropping \(3\%\) YoY to \(5.11 \text{mb / d}\) . Gasoline and diesel consumption continues to show reasonable YoY growth of \(+6\%\) and \(+3\%\) respectively, although demand declined seasonally in July due to the monsoon period. However, jet fuel demand contracted YoY for the first time since 2021 due to the aftereffects of the Ahmedabad plane crash on the country's aviation sector.

Indian refinery crude throughput rose counter- seasonally, increasing by \(1\%\) MoM to a July record of \(5.5 \text{mb / d}\) . The end of a planned TAR at the Mangalore refinery helped boost runs MoM, driving refinery outage levels back to seasonal lows.

Indian crude imports eased in July, as Russian imports fell \(17\%\) MoM. EU sanctions on the Nayara refinery in mid- July resulted in the refinery cutting run rates \(20 - 30\%\) by end- July and temporarily halting the offloading of Russian oil to the refinery's port. Narrower discounts on Russian crudes in June- July were also cited as a driver of lower Russian oil purchases. India took more oil from the Middle East (+200 kb/d) and the US (+60 kb/d) MoM to compensate for lower Russian imports.

Despite India now facing an effective US tariff rate of \(50\%\) , better discounts on Russian oil and a lack of clear directive from the government to halt Russian oil purchases have driven Indian refiners back into the Russian market. State- owned refiners were more cautious over August purchases of Russian oil, however with discounts widening on Urals, refiners have returned to the market to take advantage of the attractive economics and purchase September loading cargos.
Exhibit 1: Total oil demand fell \(325 \text{kb / d}\) MoM and was down \(130 \text{kb / d}\) YoY (- 3%) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
MORGAN STANLEY & CO. INTERNATIONAL PLC+
Equity Analyst and Commodities Strategist
Exhibit 2: Crude processing rose by \(75 \text{kb / d}\) MoM and was \(170 \text{kb / d}\) higher YoY (+3%) in July
India Crude Processing (mb/d)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 3: Crude oil imports fell by \(575 \text{kb / d}\) MoM and were \(200 \text{kb / d}\) lower YoY (- 4%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

Gasoline demand fell 40 kb/d MoM in July, in- line with seasonal trends which see depressed mobility during the monsoon period. The monsoon season in India brings widespread rainfall, which disrupts economic activity and road traffic.

Despite the MoM drop, gasoline demand continued to show healthy YoY growth of \(+6\%\) and reached a new July record of 1.0 mb/d. This is broadly in- line with average 1H 25 gasoline demand growth of \(+7\%\) YoY. Strong car sales and the summer holiday travel helped boost gasoline demand YoY.

Continued growth in gasoline demand is being supported by sales of new vehicles, with ICE vehicles still dominating sales in India. The share of vehicles powered solely by fossil fuels in total vehicles sales was \(84.5\%\) in June, outpacing EVs which only accounted for \(9\%\) of sales. Low levels of car ownership also leave room for significant growth in ICE passenger vehicles. The 2025 World Population Review found that car ownership in India is only 33 cars per 1,000 people, vs 230 per 1k in China and 850 per 1k in the US. However, commercial vehicle sales are struggling, led by YoY declines in gasoline and diesel- powertrains while growth is seen in CNG- and LPG- based vehicles. Inventory discrepancies and restricted financing options are thought to be weighing on commercial vehicle sales.

Continued changes in the gasoline vehicle fleet are also helping support gasoline demand, as more fuel- intensive SUVs capture growing market share. SUVs now constitute \(>50\%\) of passenger vehicle sales in India, while as recently as 2019 this figure was only \(\sim 26\%\) according to analysis by the Economic Times. Generally these new SUVs are displacing smaller, much less fuel- intensive hatchback cars.

However, some policy changes may create headwinds to gasoline demand further into 2026 and 2027. A draft proposal from the government of New Delhi proposes to ban the sale of fossil- fuel two- wheelers from 2027 and limit the number of fossil- fuel cars each household can purchase to two. This is part of the second phase of Delhi's EV policy, which aims to reach \(30\%\) EV penetration by 2030 (up from \(3\%\) in 2024) and tackle pollution in the city. Delhi also has a ban on diesel and gasoline vehicles (both commercial and private) older than 15 years, which came into force on April 1st 2025. Other states, such as Madhya Pradesh, are also contemplating following Delhi's example.
Looking forward, Indian gasoline demand likely recovers marginally in August, as the monsoon rains begin to wind down towards the end of the month.
Exhibit 4: Gasoline demand was down \(40\mathrm{kb / dMoM}\) but \(55\mathrm{kb / d}\) higher YoY \((+6\%)\) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research

Diesel demand fell by \(12\%\) MoM in July, in-line with seasonal trends. Heavy rains can affect the movement of commercial trucks and vehicles, which account for major domestic consumption, during the season. Irrigation activity, which also consumes a lot of diesel, also falls while the monsoon rains are ongoing.

Despite the MoM drop in demand, diesel demand still showed moderate growth in July of \(+3\%\) YoY. An early start to the Kharif crop sowing season, healthy diesel vehicle sales and strong manufacturing data are all helping drive YoY growth in diesel demand.

The S&P Global Manufacturing PMI for July increased to 59.1 from June's 58.4, marking its highest level since March 2024 and highlighting continued strength in the manufacturing sector. New orders rose sharply and at an accelerated pace, growing at the fastest rate in nearly five years, supported by robust demand conditions and successful market strategies. Consequently, output growth also picked up, reaching a fifteen- month high. Manufacturers generally remained optimistic about output growth over the next twelve months, but overall business sentiment slipped to its lowest level in three years.

Looking forward, Manufacturing PMI's for August rose to a fresh high of 59.8, marking the highest reading since January 2008 and indicating robust health in the manufacturing industry despite the tariff environment. However, India is now facing \(50\%\) tariffs on its imports into the US as of August 27th and business sentiment is worsening, which may start to weigh on the robust manufacturing activity in coming months and slow diesel demand growth.
Exhibit 5: Gasoil/diesel demand was down 250 kb/d MoM but 50 kb/d higher YoY \((+3\%)\) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in Gasoil-Diesel Consumption (kb/d)
Exhibit 6: The India Manufacturing PMI rose from 58.4 in June to 59.1 in July
India Manufacturing PMI
Source: S&P Global, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 7: India total flight numbers dropped by \(8\%\) MoM in July
India Domestic and International Flight numbers (thousands)
Source: BNEF, Morgan Stanley Research

In July, Indian jet fuel demand showed YoY contraction for the first time since March 2021. Demand was down \(6\%\) MoM and \(2\%\) YoY in July. The closure of Delhi's IGI airport for maintenance and Air India's cutback on international flights, both safety checks after the Ahmedabad plane crash and restoration of schedule stability, will have hit demand. S&P Global reports Air India reduced its international wide- body flights by \(15\%\) since June 20th and cut narrow- body domestic flights by \(5\%\) , suspending two international routes and one major domestic route while reducing frequency on 19 others.

Intensification of the monsoon rains may have also driven the demand drop vs June levels, with domestic flight numbers dropping \(9\%\) MoM in July according to BNEF's flight tracker. On a YoY basis, flight numbers only grew by \(3\%\) in July, a significant slowdown from usual YoY growth in flight numbers which have been \(>10\%\) most months this year. Slower growth in flight numbers alongside increasing fuel efficiency in planes has resulted in demand contraction YoY.
Looking forward, jet fuel demand was likely flat MoM in August as international flight numbers picked up marginally but domestic flight numbers remained broadly flat.
Exhibit 8: Jet fuel demand was down \(12 \text{kb/d MoM}\) and \(4 \text{kb/d lower YoY} (-2\%)\) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in Jet Fuel Consumption (kb/d)

Demand for fuel oil was down \(5 \text{kb/d MoM}\) in July. Monsoon rains brought cooler temperatures to India and drove a seasonal decline in fuel oil use for power generation. In the long term the use of fuel oil in south Asia has been decreasing due to the rollout of renewable energy alternatives such as hydro for power generation, or greater use of coal or gas, which reduces the need for fuel oil for power generation.
Exhibit 9: Fuel oil demand was down 5 kb/d MoM and 10 kb/d lower YoY (-9%) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in Fuel Oil Consumption (kb/d)

Naphtha demand returned to its contractionary growth pattern in July, with consumption falling \(18\%\) YoY. Persistent weakness in the regional petrochemical sector has weighed on naphtha demand in India, driving it down \(11\%\) YoY over 1H 25.

However, the longer term outlook for the Asian petrochemical sector has recently become a bit brighter. Anti- involution cutbacks in South Korea and China should cut or delay new naphtha cracking capacity and help shore up petrochemical margins, which could be beneficial for Indian petchem companies and prompt higher utilisation rates at naphtha crackers in India.
Exhibit 10: Naphtha demand was down 15 kb/d MoM and 65 kb/d lower YoY (-18%) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in Naphtha Consumption (kb/d)

LPG demand strengthened in July on cheaper LPG cylinder prices for commercial consumers. July marked the fourth consecutive month where state- controlled oil marketing companies cut prices for commercial LPG cylinders, helping boost consumption.

LPG consumption should remain strong for the rest of Q3, as the government continues to subsidize sales. India approved a \(3.4 billion compensation package earlier this month to oil marketing companies for losses incurred in selling subsidized cooking gas. The compensation approved by Prime Minister Modi, would be paid to state run Indian Oil Corp., Bharat Petroleum Corp., and Hindustan Petroleum Corp. This move aims to stabilize domestic consumption of LPG and ensure security of supply going into the autumn.
Exhibit 11: LPG-ethane demand was up 65 kb/d MoM and 45 kb/d higher YoY (+5%) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in LPG-Ethane Consumption (kb/d)

Domestic gasoline cracks sold off further in July, in- line with usual seasonal decline in demand as the monsoon season intensifies. The spread of domestic gasoline prices to Dubai averaged \(\) 3.4/\$ bbl lower MoM in July, at \(\) 4.5/\$ bbl. The monsoon rains usually depress mobility in India, putting pressure on gasoline demand. Strong gasoline refinery output over July and growing global inventories also weighed on cracks through the month. This marked the first time in three months where gasoline cracks slipped lower YoY, averaging down \(- 16\%\) YoY over the month.

Meanwhile, domestic diesel cracks strengthened further in July, rising by \(\) 2.7/\$ bbl to \(\) 17.2/\$ bbl on average over the month. This was the highest diesel cracks have been since February 2024. Low Atlantic basin inventories, elevated freight costs and tight supply of medium- sour crude were some of the several factors supporting middle distillate cracks in July, pushing the inter- basin arbitrage open. Overall, diesel cracks were tracking up \(+43\%\) YoY over July.

Looking forward, gasoline and diesel cracks reversed trend in August. Gasoline cracks strengthened in stronger travel demand while diesel cracks slipped, as tightness in the global diesel market eased as stocks began to build in the Atlantic basin.
Exhibit 12: Gasoline cracks sold off in July on soft monsoon demand...
Source: S&P Global Platts, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 13: ...while diesel cracks rallied amidst a tight global middle distillate market
Source: S&P Global Platts, Morgan Stanley Research

Indian refinery crude throughput rose \(1\%\) MoM to a new July record of \(5.5 \text{mb / d}\) . This was a counter- seasonal increase in throughput, as the monsoon season usually weighs on transport fuel demand and so refiners lower utilisation rates over summer. The end of planned maintenance at the Mangalore refinery helped boost runs, with crude throughput at the refinery rising by \(180 \text{kb / d MoM}\) . No further planned maintenance began in July, although the Nayara Vadinar refinery started an unplanned derate in late July due to new EU sanctions placed on the refinery for buying Russian oil. Overall refinery outages decreased by \(- 120 \text{kb / d MoM}\) , with average capacity offline of only \(- 80 \text{kb / d}\) .

As part of the EU's 18th sanctions package in June, the EU took action against Nayara Energy Limited, which operates the 405 kb/d Vadinar refinery in the western state of Gujarat, India's third- largest refinery. The refinery accounts for \(- 8\%\) of India's total refining capacity and \(7\%\) of its retail fuel distribution network. Vadinar was previously running at \(- 103\%\) utilisation in 1H 25, but Argus reports utilisation is now only at \(60 - 70\%\) . The refinery has had to cut runs as, although the refinery exports less than \(5\%\) of its products to Europe, Argus reports traders have been more cautious about dealing with the refiner post- sanctions and payment issues are making it difficult for companies to work with the refiner. Additionally, the refinery has faced logistical bottlenecks in ramping up supply to the domestic market. For example, the refinery has not booked sufficient truck capacity to transport products domestically, which is problematic as trucks transporting fuel are booked on a long- term tender basis.

July marked the first month since March where refinery runs showed noticeable YoY growth, up \(+3\%\) YoY. Utilisation rates moderated over Q2 25, averaging only \(- 104 - 105\%\) vs Q1 25 utilisation levels of \(- 110\%\) . Additionally, there have been above average levels of refinery

maintenance across April- June. However, in July refinery TARs fell back to low levels and utilisation levels inched up, helping boost throughput YoY. In particular, higher utilisation levels YoY have been led by IOCL's Paradip and Panipat refineries, alongside Reliance's Jamnagar and CPLC's Manali refinery.

Total output of refined products was flat MoM, despite the \(\sim 80\) kb/d uptick in crude runs. Output of refined products was also broadly flat YoY. Higher output of gasoline and LPG was offset by a reduction in jet fuel, fuel oil and naphtha volumes. Output of diesel was broadly flat MoM, as although refiners aimed to optimise diesel yields amidst strong diesel cracks, the derate of the Vadinar refinery will have impacted diesel output, as the 405 kb/d refinery has high diesel yields.

Looking forward, crude runs and refined product output will likely dip into August, as the monsoon rains continue to weigh on demand and refiners take the opportunity to conduct maintenance. BPLC's 156 kb/d Bina refinery shut down its CDU in the second week of August, which should impact diesel output but gasoline output is expected to remain relatively stable as the secondary units are unaffected. CDUs 1- 3 at IOCL's Barauni refinery are also due to head offline at the end of the month for planned maintenance. Additionally, Vortexa tanker tracking data points to a nine- month low in crude imports into India in August as Indian refiners became more cautious around taking Russian crude. Lower crude imports will also likely translate into a moderation in runs MoM.

Further upside in Indian refinery throughput is likely this year due to capacity additions in the sector. HPCL is set to commission its new 180 kb/d Barmer refinery in 2025, while IOCL is expanding capacity by 200 kb/d at its Panipat refinery. These new capacities should be online by September and December 2025, respectively. This should increase the volume of crude processed YoY, but may lower refinery utilisation rates.
Exhibit 14: Crude processing rose by 75 kb/d MoM and was up 170 kb/d YoY in July \((+3\%)\)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 15: Total refinery output was flat MoM and YoY (0%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 17: Gasoline refinery output was up 10 kb/d MoM and 90 kb/d higher YoY (+8%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 19: Fuel oil refinery output was up 35 kb/d MoM but 15 kb/d lower YoY (-7%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 16: Gasoil/diesel refinery output was up 35 kb/d MoM and was 25 kb/d higher YoY (+1%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 18: Jet fuel refinery output was flat MoM but 15 kb/d lower YoY (-4%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 20: Naphtha refinery output was up 15 kb/d MoM but down 20 kb/d YoY (-5%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 21: LPG refinery output was up 20 kb/d MoM and 10 kb/d higher YoY (+3%)
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 22: Refinery CDU outages fell by 120 kb/d MoM in July
Source: IIR, Morgan Stanley Research

Government data show Indian crude imports dropping sharply in July, falling \(\sim 575\) kb/d MoM to \(4.39\) mb/d. This was the lowest volume of crude imports on a barrels per day basis reported in the government data since September 2023. However, tanker tracking data from Vortexa shows crude imports relatively flat MoM at \(4.65\) mb/d. India received higher volumes from the Middle East \((+200\) kb/d), US \((+60\) kb/d) and Nigeria \((+45\) kb/d) MoM to compensate for a decline in Russian imports. The reason for the discrepancy between the two datasets is not clear.

Vortexa data shows imports of Russian crude into India dropped by 310 kb/d MoM to 1.48 mb/d in July, marking a five- month low in Indian imports of Russian oil. Imports dropped noticeably in the third week of July to only \(\sim 850\) kb/d, with imports of Russian crude into Vadinar port falling to only \(\sim 110\) kb/d, a third of their usual levels. The Vadinar port serves the Nayara refinery, which was hit with sanctions as part of the EU's 18th sanctions package on July 18th. Immediately post the sanctions announcement, a tanker of Russian crude was diverted away from the port. Reuters reports that the refiner has now turned to the dark fleet to facilitate continued purchases of Russian oil, with imports into Vadinar port rebounding to their usual levels of \(\sim 350\) kb/d in August (Nayara has not commented).

On top of new EU sanctions, the US has also ramped up tariffs on India based on their purchases of Russian oil. On 28th July, President Trump announced he was moving forward a deadline to 8th August for Russia to make progress in peace talks with Ukraine or face unspecified US sanctions, shortening the previous 50- day deadline. President Trump also announced there would be \(25\%\) "reciprocal" trade tariffs on India from August 1st (up from \(10\%\) previously) plus an additional punitive tariff, owing to the large quantities of Russian oil the country buys. On August 6th, President Trump revealed the extra tariff would take the form of additional \(25\%\) tariffs that would come into place on August 27th, taking India's effective tariff rate to \(50\%\) .

The uncertainty created by US tariffs may weigh on Russian volumes into India over August and September. Due to the prospect of US sanctions/tariffs disrupting Russian crude deliveries to India, state refiners went into the spot market in late July/early August and bought US, Middle Eastern and West African grades for September- October delivery. These state- refiners ordinarily account for \(\sim 35\%\) of Russian crude imports to India.

However, unattractive pricing was also given as a reason why Indian state- owned refiners reduced buying of Russian oil in July. Discounts on Russian oil also reached their narrowest since 2022 in July, with Urals pricing at only a \(1.5 / \mathrm{bb}\) discount to dated Brent as lower exports from Russia and solid demand pushed Urals prices up. Lower purchases in July will depress August and September imports.

As discounts on Russian crude widen again, Indian buyers have been returning to the market. Discounts on Russian oil have since risen to \(2 - 3 / \mathrm{bb}\) vs Brent by late August, as Russia has offered deep discounts on its crude due to damage to domestic refining capacity from Ukrainian drone strikes. This has prompted state- owned refiners to return to buying October delivery Urals cargos. Argus also reports that Indian private sector refiner Reliance is expected to continue importing Russian oil under their term- contract with Rosneft (Reliance has not commented on the article). With widening discounts and no clear policy directive from the Indian government ordering refiners not to buy Russian crude, it seems likely that Russian imports will recover to normal levels of \(1.6 - 1.7\) mb/d in October/November.
Exhibit 23: Crude imports were down 575 kb/d MoM and 200 kb/d lower YoY (-4%) in July
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
YoY Growth in Crude Imports (mb/d)
Exhibit 24: India took less crude from Russia in July, instead importing more Arab Gulf and US crudes...
India seaborne crude imports by origin country
Source: Vortexa, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 25: ...driving Russia's share of Indian crude supplies to fall to a 4-month low.
Share of Indian seaborne imports
Source: Vortexa, Morgan Stanley Research

Total net exports of products fell by 90 kb/d MoM in July, as export margins weakened. Net exports declined across all clean products despite lower domestic consumption and higher crude processing levels. Diesel exports fell as India reduced volumes into the regional market and instead shipped more diesel to NW Europe on a tight European diesel market. Indian refiners raised gasoline exports to the US by 20% MoM in July, but also reduced exports into the regional market.

Imports of LPG normalised in July, following strong June import levels. US LPG prices dropped sharply in May, as China placed 125% retaliatory tariffs on imports of US LPG. China is the major buyer of US LPG, so a reduction in China purchases in May drove a surplus in US LPG cargos that Indian refiners took advantage of. Indian imports of US LPG rose +27% MoM as a result. However, US LPG prices normalised once the 125% tariff was removed in mid- May, prompting purchases by Indian refiners to drop from 300 kb/d in June to 65 kb/d in July.
Looking forward, tanker tracking data indicate clean product exports should rise in August on greater diesel and gasoline exports.
Exhibit 26: Total net product exports fell 90 kb/d MoM but were 170 kb/d higher YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 28: Gasoline net exports were down 35 kb/d MoM but 55 kb/d higher YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 30: Fuel oil exports were down 20 kb/d MoM but 30 kb/d higher YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 27: Gasoil/diesel exports were down 20 kb/d MoM but 40 kb/d higher YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 29: Jet fuel net exports were down 15 kb/d MoM and 20 kb/d lower YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 31: Naphtha exports were down 35 kb/d MoM but 60 kb/d higher YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 32: LPG net exports were up 15 kb/d MoM but 20 kb/d lower YoY
Source: India Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 33: India increased product exports to the EU and Brazil, while decreasing exports to the UAE and Australia
Source: Vortexa, Morgan Stanley Research

Base case, EV/EBITDA- based SOTP:

Refining: F2027e EV/EBITDA of \(6.5x,\) in line with global comps for refining peers. Fuel marketing: F2027e EV/EBITDA of \(7.0x,\) in line with global comps for marketing peers. We believe in- line multiples are appropriate for a commodity business given EBITDA and EBITDA margin outlook, along with quality of debt and capex. BPCL's listed investments: \(40\%\) discount to market price, reflecting market volatility risks.
Market share gains in fuel retailing. Faster than expected completion of Bina upgradation project Progress in Mozambique asset.
Government control of fuel prices if oil prices spike. Market share in key fuels falls drastically Bina projects and city gas projects stall resulting in cost overruns.

Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
Morgan Stanley Research policy is to update research reports as and when the Research Analyst and Research Management deem appropriate, based on developments with the issuer, the

sector, or the market that may have a material impact on the research views or opinions stated therein. In addition, certain Research publications are intended to be updated on a regular periodic basis (weekly/monthly/quarterly/annual) and will ordinarily be updated with that frequency, unless the Research Analyst and Research Management determine that a different publication schedule is appropriate based on current conditions.

in July, following strong June import levels. US LPG prices dropped sharply in May, as China placed 125% retaliatory tariffs on imports of US LPG. China is the major buyer of US LPG, so a reduction in

ve a surplus in US LPG cargos that Indian refiners took advantage of. Indian imports of US LPG rose +27% MoM as a result. However, US LPG prices normalised once the 125% tariff was removed in mid- May
